Is The Perception of Sexual Violence in America Sexist?

What’s really going on with the gender gap in sexual violence?

Daniel Goldman
Apr 25

First, a disclaimer. There’s some content in this discussion that might not be appropriate for all audiences. Victims of sexual violence may also feel uncomfortable reading this article. However, it’s important to understand the nature of sexual violence in the United States, and around the world. Only through a proper understanding can we find a solution.

There’s a troubling misconception about rape. Generally, rape is considered a problem faced by women, and perpetrated by men. Official statistics in many ways “support” this notion. But for reasons that I will mention in the rest of this discussion, those figures aren’t reasonable. And as more research is being conducted, we’re learning more about the previously voiceless victims of rape.

Do Men Rape? An Issue of Definitions

According to the CDC, only 1 in 71 men have been victims of rape in their lifetime. But there’s an issue. The definition of rape that the CDC uses seems rather bizarre and extremely limited. But it’s difficult to tell. One issue is that a lot of commentary and research on rape doesn’t seem to explicitly define rape. According to the same report, 1 in 21 men have been made to penetrate. So it seems that the rate of rape among men should be at least 1 in 21. But those instances of sexual violence aren’t included. Why isn’t that rape?

Unfortunately the legal definition of rape is fairly limited: “The penetration, no matter how slight, of the vagina or anus with any body part or object, or oral penetration by a sex organ of another person, without the consent of the victim.” From 1927, until 2012, the definition of rape was even more limited, only including “forcible male penile penetration of a female vagina.” In other words, up until 2012, there was no legal concept of rape of a male. While technically these definitions can vary on more local levels, these definitions are what have been used for the uniform crime reporting system (UCR) which is used for a lot of research and data collection on crime.

Still, being forced to penetrate someone else, handling of a man’s penis, etc are not considered rape. It’s hard to explain why, aside from the apparent idea that it’s somehow worse to violate a female sexual organ than it is to violate a male’s. I would probably also include unwelcomed contact with breasts, however common view that breasts are not sexual in nature may have something to do with their exclusion. But either way, the penis is definitely a sex organ, so any unwelcomed contact of it should be included in rape figures. The definition of rape that’s commonly used just doesn’t make sense, if we’re going to include male rape victims.

Perceptions and Reality

So the definition of rape, used by many government entities, is itself biased against male victims. But there are other issues as well. Male rape goes under-reported, in part because of the persistent notion that rape is a problem that’s almost exclusively faced by women. Moreover, males are almost exclusively seen as the perpetrators of rape. While there is likely a gender gap, a good chunk of this perception is likely due to the historical definitions of rape.

Laura Stemple and her associates have been studying sexual victimization committed by women. The research has uncovered a number of issues with historical figures. Their data suggests that rape by women is not rare, contrary to popular belief. They also found that women are much less likely to face legal consequences for their victimization. They also cite a CDC report by Breiding et al. This report has some rather odd information in it. According to the report, female rape victims outnumbered male rape victims by a factor of ten to one. Yet, during the 12 month period being studied, roughly an equal number of men and women — roughly 1.9 million each — reported being victims of rape. Either that essentially random 12 month period was very unusual, or there is something else skewing the statistics, such as the historically biased view of rape.

Moving Foward

We need a definition of rape that’s reasonable and which isn’t biased towards or against a given sex. We also need to see improvements in scientific literature involving rape. Given the issues that I’ve discussed in this article, improvement of research on this topic should include ensuring that the definition of rape being used be explicitly stated within papers relating to the topic. Rape is not so well defined that we can just know what an author means when they say that rape occurs at a certain rate.

Of course, none of this discussion is meant to reduce the importance of female rape victims. Instead, it seeks to shine a light on the understudied and poorly discussed issue of male rape victims and female offenders, and seeks to show how the current view of sexual violence in the United States is inherently biased against males. In order to help solve the problem of sexual violence, we must understand that problem. And a sexist attitude towards rape is not going to help us understand anything at all.
